content.description: “Young people, nowadays, [said Lord Fermor] imagine that money is everything.” “Yes,” murmured Lord Henry, ...“and when they grow older they know it.” —Oscar Wilde, The Picture of Dorian Gray (1891) Either from your own reading or from the list, choose a work of fiction in which a character’s attitude toward money illustrates or contradicts Lord Henry’s observation. Then, in a well-written essay, analyze how the complex role of money in the character’s life contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole. Awake and Sing! Brideshead Revisited The Cherry Orchard Crime and Punishment Death of a Salesman A Doll House Emma Glengarry Glen Ross The Godfather The Grapes of Wrath Great Expectations The Great Gatsby A Hologram for the King The House of Mirth Howards End Jane Eyre Lady Windermere’s Fan Linden Hills Lucky Jim Major Barbara McTeague The Merchant of Venice Middlemarch Moll Flanders Money The Piano Lesson A Raisin in the Sun The Rise of Silas Lapham Silas Marner Sister Carrie Song of Solomon A Streetcar Named Desire Their Eyes Were Watching God A Thousand Splendid Suns Vanity Fair The Visit The White Tiger

frqParts.text: In a well-written essay, analyze how the complex role of money in the character’s life contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole. In your response, you should do the following: Respond to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation. Provide evidence to support your line of reasoning. Explain how the evidence supports your line of reasoning. Use appropriate grammar and punctuation in communicating your argument.

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Identify and describe what specific textual details reveal about a character, that character's perspective, and that character's motives.
